name: CustomMatcher
comment:
A useful utility class for implementing other matchers through inheritance. Derived classes should call the base constructor with a feature name and description, and an instance matcher, and should implement the unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.featureValueOf abstract method.

The feature description will typically describe the item and the feature, while the feature name will just name the feature. For example, we may have a Widget class where each Widget has a price; we could make a unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher that can make assertions about prices with:

class HasPrice extends CustomMatcher {
  const HasPrice(matcher) :
      super("Widget with price that is", "price", matcher);
  featureValueOf(actual) => actual.price;
}

and then use this for example like:

 expect(inventoryItem, new HasPrice(greaterThan(0)));

describe.name: describe
describe.comment: This builds a textual description of the matcher.

describeMismatch.name: describeMismatch
describeMismatch.comment: This builds a textual description of a specific mismatch. unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.item is the value that was tested by unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches; unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.matchState is the dart-core.Map that was passed to and supplemented by unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches with additional information about the mismact, and unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.mismatchDescription is the unittest/matcher.Description that is being built to decribe the mismatch. A few matchers make use of the unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.verbose flag to provide detailed information that is not typically included but can be of help in diagnosing failures, such as stack traces.

featureValueOf.name: featureValueOf
featureValueOf.comment: Override this to extract the interesting feature.

matches.name: matches
matches.comment: This does the matching of the actual vs expected values. unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches.item is the actual value. unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches.matchState can be supplied and may be used to add details about the mismatch that are too costly to determine in unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

describe.name: describe
describe.comment: This builds a textual description of the matcher.

describeMismatch.name: describeMismatch
describeMismatch.comment: This builds a textual description of a specific mismatch. unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.item is the value that was tested by unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches; unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.matchState is the dart-core.Map that was passed to and supplemented by unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches with additional information about the mismact, and unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.mismatchDescription is the unittest/matcher.Description that is being built to decribe the mismatch. A few matchers make use of the unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.verbose flag to provide detailed information that is not typically included but can be of help in diagnosing failures, such as stack traces.

matches.name: matches
matches.comment: This does the matching of the actual vs expected values. unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches.item is the actual value. unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.matches.matchState can be supplied and may be used to add details about the mismatch that are too costly to determine in unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.describeMismatch.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of unittest/matcher.CustomMatcher.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.
